message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest rotator cuff tear, which commonly occurs in athletes involved in overhead activities such as volleyball. The pain worsens with arm elevation and abduction, and there is point tenderness on palpation of the anterolateral aspect of the left shoulder. IV disk protrusion at the C4-5 level would present with neck pain and may cause radicular symptoms. Intra-articular humeral fracture and shoulder joint dislocation would cause significant swelling and deformity which the patient does not exhibit. Hence, the most likely cause of this patient’s condition is Tear of the supraspinatus muscle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a rotator cuff injury, which typically involves the supraspinatus muscle. The point tenderness to palpation and pain with elevation and abduction of the left arm further support this diagnosis. The other options are less likely given the absence of relevant findings on physical examination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including pain in the anterolateral aspect of the shoulder and restricted abduction with passive abduction causing pain, suggest that the most likely cause is a tear of the supraspinatus muscle. The absence of swelling or bony deformities makes the fractures and dislocations less likely. IV disk protrusion at the C4-5 level is associated with neck and arm pain, not isolated shoulder pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest rotator cuff injury, which includes tears of the supraspinatus muscle. There is point tenderness on the anterolateral aspect of the left shoulder, restricted abduction, and pain during passive abduction. A herniated disc in the cervical spine may cause radiculopathy rather than localized shoulder pain. Shoulder joint dislocation and intra-articular humeral fractures would result in more significant deformities and limitations in range of motion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with a rotator cuff injury, specifically a tear of the supraspinatus muscle given the pain with arm elevation and abduction, point tenderness, and reduced strength. The other options are less likely given the absence of other symptoms or physical examination findings to support them.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including pain when elevating the left arm and point tenderness to palpation on the anterolateral aspect of the left shoulder, suggest a tear of the supraspinatus muscle. The other options would present with different symptoms and findings on physical examination.

We refer to a reliable medical source such as the Merck Manual for help. The patient’s symptoms point towards a tear of the supraspinatus muscle. The pain worsens with elevating or abducting the left arm, and there is point tenderness to palpation of the anterolateral aspect of the left shoulder. Limited range of active motion, normal range of passive motion with pain, and reduced strength supports this diagnosis. IV disk protrusion at the C4-5 level would typically present with neck pain and radicular pain in the lower cervical dermatomes. Intra-articular humeral fracture would present with pain, swelling, and decreased range of motion with strength unaffected unless it is a severe fracture. Shoulder joint dislocation would present with pain, swelling, instability, and limited range of motion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest rotator cuff injury, specifically tear of the supraspinatus muscle. The pain with elevating the arm and point tenderness to palpation support this diagnosis, while the lack of swelling or bony deformities rules out a fracture or dislocation. IV disk protrusion at the C4-5 level would present with different symptoms, such as neck pain and upper extremity paresthesias.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation of point tenderness and pain with abduction of the arm suggests a possible rotator cuff tear. Among the options, Tear of the supraspinatus muscle is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition, especially with normal passive range of motion and intact sensation. IV disk protrusion at the C4-5 level will cause neck pain and possible radicular symptoms. Intra-articular humeral fracture and Shoulder joint dislocation usually present with more significant findings on physical examination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest the most likely cause is a tear of the supraspinatus muscle due to the point tenderness and pain with abduction of the left arm. IV disk protrusion at C4-5 level can cause neck and arm pain, but not shoulder pain. Intra-articular humeral fracture and shoulder joint dislocation usually cause significant swelling and bony deformities.
